question: Which property of Pluto explains why its surface gravity is the weakest among the nine planets?

content.source_1: Pluto is a dwarf planet orbiting the Sun and has far less mass than any of the eight classical planets.
content.source_2: Mercury is the least massive of the eight classical planets, yet it is still more than twenty times as massive as Pluto.
content.source_3: For planets and similar bodies, surface gravity increases with mass and, because planetary radius generally increases with mass, the least massive body in a set will typically have the weakest surface gravity (g ∝ M/R^2).
content.source_4: Saturn has the lowest mean density of any planet in the Solar System—less than that of liquid water.
content.source_5: For a given mass, a lower-density sphere has a larger radius and therefore a lower surface gravity (g = GM/R^2).
content.source_6: Saturn rotates rapidly and is strongly oblate, which reduces the effective gravitational acceleration at its equator compared with a non-rotating sphere.
